Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão

Bolsista de Produtividade em Pesquisa do CNPq - Nível 1D

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/5174466549126882
  • Última atualização do currículo em 03/05/2019

Possui graduação em Biociências e Biotecnologia pela Universidade Estadual do Norte Fluminense (1997), mestrado em Biociências e Biotecnologia pela Universidade Estadual do Norte Fluminense (2000), doutorado em Sensoriamento Remoto pelo Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (2004) com Doutorado Sanduíche - University of Edinburgh (2003). Possui Pós-Doutorado pela University of Oxford (2004-2008). Atua como Professor Associado na University of Exeter-UK e atualmente é Pesquisador do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (INPE). Atua como chefe da Divisão de Sensoriamento Remoto e coordena o Grupo de Pesquisa TREES (Tropical Ecosystems and Environmental Sciences group). Serve como revisor para os renomados periódicos: Nature, Science, PLOS One, Proceedings of the National Academy of Science, Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society-B, New Phytologist, Ecological applications, entre outros. Publicou como primeiro autor nos periódicos Science e Nature. Em 2006 foi agraciado com o premio Merit Award pela Universidade de Oxford, Inglaterra e com a prestigiosa Fellowship do Natural Environment Research Council-UK em 2008. Tem experiência na área de Ecossistemas Tropicais e ciências ambientais, com ênfase em Sensoriamento Remoto, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: dinâmica de carbono, mudanças climáticas e ambientais, ecologia de ecossistemas e paisagem, sensoriamento remoto de distúrbios florestais. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - Atual
Effects of soil fertility on the carbon cycle of tropical forests: A novel soil fertility manipulation experiment in Amazonia (AFEX)
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Carlos Alberto Nobre Quesada em 08/08/2016.
Descrição: Descrição: Determining how tree growth and carbon storage in tropical forests is controlled, and will respond to global change, remains one of the most important priorities for climate change research, and has major implications for the 10s of millions of people who live in rainforest regions. In temperate ecosystems, manipulative experiments have greatly improved our understanding of the degree to which nitrogen (N) availability controls ecosystem functioning, and it has been shown that previous failure to incorporate N limitation into models led to potentially erroneous predictions of responses to both elevated CO2 and climate change. In contrast to temperate systems, one of the most important paradigms in tropical ecology is that the productivity of forests growing on highly-weathered ?infertile? tropical soils is limited by phosphorus (P) availability. However, due to the inter-related nature of many variables [e.g. rainfall, disturbance, soil structure and nutrient availability], meta-analyses of carbon-nutrient-climate relationships have been unable to produce unequivocal support for the phosphorus paradigm. This has led to recent high-profile reviews emphasising the urgent need for experimental manipulation studies to identify how nutrient availability controls tropical forest productivity, as well as the incorporation of this understanding into Earth Systems models. Critically, this endeavour is undermined by the fact that, to date, no large-scale, long-term, nutrient-manipulation study has been carried out on the low-fertility soils characteristic of huge areas of the largest tropical rainforest, the Amazon. Because global change is likely to have different effects on the availability of different nutrients, determining which nutrients play the greatest role in controlling Amazon forest productivity is extremely important for accurately simulating future rates of C uptake in this globally significant ecosystem. We propose to implement the first large-scale nutrient-addition experiment in Amazonia, and will determine the responses of all key components of the forest C cycle. Importantly, we will then use the understanding developed to improve process-representation in a dynamic global vegetation model (DGVM)...
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Integrante / QUESADA, CARLOS A. - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Natural Environment Research Council - Auxílio financeiro.
2014 - Atual
Quantificação de áreas florestais queimadas e modelagem de emissões de carbono: Proposta de um sistema de monitoramento integrado para a Amazônia? - FATE-Amazônia
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Coordenador / Paulo Maurício Graça - Integrante / Liana O Anderson - Integrante / Jos Barlow - Integrante / ARAI, EGIDIO - Integrante / Yosio E Shimabukuro - Integrante / Toby A. Gardner - Integrante / Joice Ferreira - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico - Auxílio financeiro.
2013 - Atual
Pre-Columbian Amazon-Scale Transformations
Descrição: The protection of rainforests and the development of sustainable land-use practices in the humid tropics are of global significance because these forests represent a major reservoir of biodiversity and are of crucial importance for the regulation of Earth?s climate. A sound understanding of the historical role of humans in shaping Amazonian landscapes and to what extent Amazonian forests were resilient to historical disturbance is critical to make informed policy decisions about sustainable Amazonian futures. However, the nature and scale of pre-Columbian land use and its modern legacy on Amazonian landscapes are among the most debated topics in New World archaeology, palaeoecology and conservation. To resolve this debate, this project will investigate the influence of the late pre-Columbian (1000-1492 A.D.) land use on Amazonian landscapes, the impact of the 1492 Columbian Encounter (CE) and its modern legacy through the comparative study of pre-Columbian land uses in four different regions of Amazonia. It will apply, for the first time, an innovative interdisciplinary approach that integrates archaeology, ethnohistory, archaeobotany, paleoecology, soil science, landscape ecology and remote sensing (including the novel application of LIDAR survey) to the following study regions: (1) the Santarem Amazonian Dark Earth sites in the Lower Amazon, (2) the interfluvial areas of the Purus-Madeira Rivers in the Central Amazon, (3) the Acre geoglyphs of SW Amazonia and (4) the ring-ditches of the Baures forested areas of the Bolivian Amazon. The results of the project have broader implications not only for archaeology and geography but for conservation and sustainable Amazonian futures.".
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Coordenador / Jose Iriarte - Integrante.
Financiador(es): European Research Council - Auxílio financeiro.
2013 - Atual
Understanding the response of photosynthetic metabolism in tropical forests to seasonal climate variations
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Coordenador / Liana O Anderson - Integrante / ARAI, EGIDIO - Integrante / Yosio E Shimabukuro - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Auxílio financeiro.
2013 - Atual
ECOFOR: Biodiversity and Eco-system Functioning in Degraded and Recovering Amazonian and Atlantic Forests.
Descrição: This NERC-FAPESP funded project aims to deliver a step-change in our understanding of the consequences of forest degradation and regeneration for biodiversity and associated ecological processes and services in Amazon and Atlantic Forests. To achieve this, we will: 1) establish the first intensive network of long-term monitoring sites along a gradient from intact to severely altered forests in the Brazilian Amazon, and significantly enhance the existing network of modified and intact sites in the Atlantic Forest; 2) complement these intensive-sites with a network of extensive study plots across multiple catchments in the Amazon and the Atlantic Forest, enabling us to answer questions about changes in biodiversity, functional traits and carbon stocks at the landscape level; 3) develop an integrated research framework that links the data and process understanding from both intensive and extensive observations of human-modified gradients to model policy options across our study landscapes.. Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Integrante / BARLOW, J. - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Natural Environment Research Council - Auxílio financeiro.

2011 - 2014
Drought, fire and society: Understanding the impacts of potential climate change-induced hazards on human health in Amazonia
Descrição: The general goal of this project is to explicitly quantify the basin-wide impacts of droughts, deforestation and fires, the three major environmental issues anticipated to affect Amazon region in the 21st century, on the health of the Amazonian population and understand how the risk of diseases may change onto the future due to environmental and climate changes..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Luiz Eduardo Oliveira e Cruz de Aragão - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Natural Environment Research Council - Bolsa.
